intro: Silene scabriflora var. sabuletorum, commonly known as the sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves, which help it retain moisture in arid environments. The plant produces small, pink or white flowers that bloom in clusters, typically during the spring and summer months. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in desert scrub and coastal dunes. Silene scabriflora var. sabuletorum is adapted to withstand extreme temperatures and is an important part of its local ecosystem.
